title: philip hammond should budget disappointment
story: NewsopinionPhilip Hammond should budget for disappointment: Mirror Politics morning briefingThe Chancellor will call time on austerity when he delivers his Budget. He should not expect any gratitudeShareCommentsByJason BeattieHead of politics:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsopinionPhilip Hammond is not someone used to delivering cheer "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Philip Hammond is not normally a person who delivers cheer. He has the appearance of Uriah Heep, without the ‘umbleness, and the charisma of a filing cabinet with a wonky drawer. Yet when he stands up this afternoon to deliver his Budget he will try to turn Halloween into Christmas. On Theresa May’s insistence he will shake the magic money tree to an inch of its roots in order to splash the cash on the NHS, social care, transport, mental health and a free pumpkin for everyone. We are being asked to believe that austerity is officially over. The Chancellor should enjoy the cheers from the Conservative benches while he can. This, like all financial statements since June , will be built on fiction. The country’s fortunes rest entirely on what happens with Brexit and until that is resolved then all forecasts, promises, economic planning and investments are impossible to guarantee. A no deal Brexit would see austerity galloping back quicker than the winner at Newmarket – a point Hammond almost delighted in telling us yesterday . That is not the only dficulty facing the Chancellor. His most pressing task is finding the money to pay for the additional funding. With every Budget it is advisable to read the small print but it will be especially so today. The Conservatives, remember, are very good at demanding extra investment but very adverse to finding ways of paying for it. They still believe you can have high levels of public services with low levels of taxation. The greater challenge for the Government is convincing people austerity really has finished.

title: what time budget speech 2018
story: NewsWhat time is the Budget today  How to watch Chancellor Philip Hammonds speech and whats in itChancellor Philip Hammond will start his Autumn Budget  this afternoon. Here are confirmed policies and predictions - including measures on fuel duty, roads and the high streetShareCommentsByMikey SmithPolitical reporterDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsChancellor Philip Hammond says his plans will build a stronger, more prosperous economy "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe UK is braced for its final Budget before leaving the EU. Chancellor Philip Hammond claims his statement today will show your hard work is paying off as he turns on spending taps for roads, high streets and fuel. But he faces furious demands to go further by pumping more money into the Universal Credit benefit. And hes admitted he wont fulfil Theresa Mays pledge to end austerity - instead only doing it next year,theres a Brexit deal. If there isnt a Brexit deal, he said the entire Budget will have to be done again. Although, confusingly, Downing Street then insisted todays commitments will be funded irrespective of a Brexit deal.  Meanwhile the PM piled more pressure on his balance sheet by announcing an extension of a freeze on fuel duty and lting the cap on council borrowing to build new homes. Heres everything we know that is in the Budget so far - and how itll hit you.  A statement made by the Chancellor of the Exchequer on his plans for tax, public spending and economic forecasts. MPs vote on whether to accept it. It would be incredibly seriousthe Budget did not pass, and could lead to a vote of no confidence in the government. Traditionally the governing party has gone to all sorts of s to persuade MPs to vote for the Finance Bill. Theresa May doesnt have a majority. And Northern Irelands DUP, who prop up the Tories, may flex their muscles and threaten to torpedo the vote.  The  Budget will take place at .pm this afternoon. Its claimed the Chancellor initially wanted the Budget to be on Wednesday  October - but thought holding it on Halloween might not bode well. How can I watch the Budget  The Budget will be screened on live news channels and Mirror, where you can watch a live feed with rolling text analysis here. Isnt the Budget in the spring   It used to be, but in  Chancellor Philip Hammond moved the Budget from Spring to Autumn. This new system replaces the Autumn Statement, which moved to become a Spring Statement , a lower-key affair. How will Brexit affect the Budget   The Budget is taking place before Britain knows for sureit has a Brexit deal - and before MPs get a chance to vote on that deal. If there is a No Deal Brexit, frankly wed need to have a new budget that set out a dferent strategy for the future, Philip Hammond admitted.  Its the only time a minister is allowed to quaff alcohol at the Commons despatch box. But given hes nicknamed Eeyore and compared to an accountant, dont expect Philip Hammond to be swigging the Special Brew. In fact, the last Chancellor to enjoy a tipple at the despatch box was Kenneth Clarke in . CONFIRMED policies in the Budget  The state of the nation - and MORE spending  The Budget will begin with major projections on GDP, borrowing and debt. These frame every decision because they show how much money there is to spend. And the Chancellor has claimed there WILL be more money to spend. Borrowing has come in lower than we expected, Philip Hammond told the BBC. Public finances are performing strongly. And he told Sky News: We are now at a turning point. Our debt is falling. The public finances are performing better and people now want to know that there is a little bit of relief coming down the line. The Financial Times has reported therell be a surprise “pound billion annual windfall” in the budget, which will help avoid hiking taxes to pay for Theresa Mays pledge to plough an extra pound billion a year into the NHS by . poundbillion a year extra for mental health  Spending on mental health will rise by at least pound billion a year by , in a push to improve access to rapid care for people in crisis. The announcements will include more specialist mental health ambulance services and comprehensive support in every major AE department. And Mr Hammond will promise improved access to services in the community, including ‘crisis cafes’ - community spaces for people to access support without going to AE. A new NHS work placement and support scheme will help , adults suffering severe mental health issues into work, the Treasury says.  The Budget will pave the way for offering no-interest loans to the three million poor borrowers who use payday lenders. Banks and debt charities will get poundmillion to help them design no-cost repayment plans for les unexpected costs. Meanwhile there will be detailed proposals to increase the breathing space for debt-ridden families from six weeks to  days. That means they would get two months before bailfs can take action. The changes were welcomed by MoneySavingExpert founder Martin Lewis, but he said the only disappointment was the y timetable - with no concrete policy announced yet. Shadow Chancellor John McDonnell added: This is farcical from a Government that has overseen the expansion of high-cost problem credit on an industrial scale. And whose flagship social security policy, Universal Credit, is driving low-income households into debt.  Philip Hammond is to announce a pound.billion mega boost for our dying high streets in a major victory for the Daily Mirror. Our High Street Fightback campaign has urged the Government to take urgent action to save our traditional high street shops and local businesses with tens of thousands of jobs being lost every year. Now the Chancellor is set to use his Budget to announce a triple whammy of measures for high streets. He will slash business rate bills by a third in a poundmillion boost for almost half a million small retailers. And he is to launch a poundmillion infrastructure and transport fund to transform high streets to help them remain firmly at the heart of communities. Mr Hammond will also announce that town planning laws are to be relaxed to help support mixed business models.  Major roads will be able to access a pound.bn fund from  to , the Chancellor will claim - eclipsing the pound.bn in the previous five years. It will be funded by deciding for the first time that road taxmust be dedicated in full to roads. The money will be split into the standard Roads Investment Strategy  , plus pound.bn for major local routes. Meanwhile there will also be a poundm pothole-filling fund for councils, who have spent years warning drastic Tory cuts leave them doing the bare mininum. Some poundm will go into the Transforming Cities Fund, which funds bus routes, trams and cycle lanes, in  . Another poundm in   and poundm in   will be spent trying to improve gridlocked local junctions. And poundm will be spent between   and   on trials of next-generation transport in three city regions to look at self-driving shuttles and electric bikes. Cheaper weddings  Wedding venues could get cheaper as more pubs and restaurants open their doors in a legal shake-up promised as part of next weeks budget. Treasury officials say that red tape is stopping many smaller businesses from obtaining a licence - pushing up the costs for couples. They say relaxing the restrictions would make it cheaper and simpler for couples to get married, potentially supporting more people to get married. Surveys show the average wedding costs between pound, and pound,, which includes an average cost of around pound, for venue hire. The Chancellor is set to announce a review of marriage law in Mondays budget when he is expected to say he wants to make the outdated rules around wedding venues simpler and fairer, and reduce red tape. He is expected to say this will reduce costs for couple who want to tie the knot.  The Budget will freeze fuel duty for the ninth year in a row - a tax cut that her Chancellor Philip Hammond admits will come at signicant cost to the nation. It will benefit hard-pressed motorists but comes as other groups continue to struggle - with working-age benefits still frozen for four years to . Tory officials suggest the average motorist has gained about pound, in total from all the freezes since . Now compare that to the utterly astronomical cost. The Institute for Fiscal Studies estimates the cumulative effect of all those freezes is now costing the Treasury poundbillion a year. Thats more than the affordable housing budget and more than DOUBLE the amount gained by the government by freezing millions of peoples benefits.  million trees!  The Chancellor will pledge to spend pound million planting an estimated  million trees across England. pound million of that figure will be spent on planting trees in cities and urban areas. The remaining pound million will be paid to landowners who plant forests on their land, buying so-called ‘carbon credits’ from them which the Government can offset against fossil fuel emissions to hit global anti-climate change targets. The budget will also approve plans for a new “Great Thames Park” in London’s Thames Estuary. More money for broadband  The Chancellor signalled he was ready to invest billions in Britains infrastructure - like superfast broadband - in an interview with The Sunday . Sometimes the easiest thing for a government to cut in the short termits under pressure is capital investment, he said. It is the spending on the skills of the next generation, the infrastructure, including the digital infrastructure, the broadband infrastructure. For the st century broadband is to roads in the th, railways in the th, and canals in the th. Its the network infrastructure that will make this country work.  Fury is mounting, including on Tory benches, about the harm caused by flagship welfare shake-up Universal Credit. Last years Budget saw pound.billion put in - but critics say it was not enough because it has, since its launch in , been bundled up with billions in austerity-driven benefit cuts. Tory Chief Secretary to the Treasury Liz Truss admitted: We are listening very carefully to what our colleagues have to say… we want this system to work. The BBC obtained leaked plans to offer higher transition payments, lower loan repayments and more help for the self-employed. These plans would cost hundreds of millions of pounds.  But crucially its thought Tory ministers are looking at smoothing the transition to people who migrate to UC - NOT helping the million new claimants who will be on it by December . Chancellor Philip Hammond told Sky News: Well we continue to look at how this process is working andwe find clf edges and dficulties, frictions in the move from the old benefits system to Universal Credit then of course will always try to smooth those out and be pragmatic about it. The Mirror are demanding a halt to the expansion of Universal Credit and for a review to take place. We say there are three options:Redesign UC to be fit for purpose Axe it in favour of the old systemUC is unfixable Introduce a brand new systemSign our petition to stop the rollout of Universal Credit across Britain and to replace it with a fairer system by signing our petition. Philip Hammond is expected to shelve a . per cent rise in beer duty which would have put p on a pint, the Sunday Mirror reports. Its because because better than expected tax receipts have given him an extra poundbillion to play with. But a p hike on a bottle of still wine and p on sparkling is on the cards. Spirits are likely to go up p a bottle and cigarettes p a pack. More money for social care The Chancellor has been considering a cash boost of almost poundbillion for social care to ease a national crisis, the Mail on Sunday reports. More money for the Armed Forces Multiple reports suggested Defence Secretary Gavin Williamson had secured around poundm extra for the Armed Forces. A tax ultimatum to web giants - but no action yet  Philip Hammond signalled his determination to pursue a digital tax - to ensure internet giants like Facebook pay a greater share of their profits. But it might not come straight away. He told the Sunday : Were not going to just talk about this forever. Were going to have to have a timetable for moving forward and were going to have to set some deadlines. Rumours of what COULD be in the Budget An income tax rise Tax rises were widely expected in the Budget after Theresa May promised a poundbillion pot for the NHS. One idea is the Tories could tear up their election pledge to raise the threshold at which workers start paying Income Tax. Ministers pledged to raise the tax-free allowance to pound, and the p rate starting salary to pound,. The moves are currently in progress, inching forward a little each year. But delaying or scrapping further rises could save billions. A VAT raid on small businesses The Chancellor had examined plans to drag hundreds of thousands of small businesses into the VAT system, according to the Daily Mail. Currently firms only have to charge VAT their turnover tops pound, a year. Halving that threshold to pound, could raise pound.billion but hit half a million small firms. A big hit to pay rises for nurses, teachers and police Unions have mounted a furious backlash at reported plans to curb the pay of five million public sector workers. The Government had won plaudits last year after it finally bowed to pressure and axed the % pay cap. But the Chancellor was planning to plug the enormous black hole in Tory finances by banning blanket pay rises across the board for nurses, teachers and police officers, it was reported. Its said that future wage increases will instead be based on people’s performance and where they live in the country. Dave Prentis, general secretary of Unison, Britain’s biggest public services union, warned: “What regional pay means in practice is further attacks on the wages of NHS staff, school staff, police staff and others. A hit to fossil fuel giants The Treasury was considering hiking the climate change levy on firms’ use of fossil fuels to raise an extra pound million a year, the Sun reported. A crackdown on offshore gambling firms Tax will be hiked on offshore gambling firms in a move to raise poundbn over five years, the Financial Times reported. This would supposedly fill a tax black hole left by the widely-welcomed crackdown on crack cocaine fixed-odds betting machines. One policy that WONT be in the Budget The end of austerity  Theresa May proclaimed austerity is over in her Tory conference speech in September. But benefits remain frozen until , effectively cutting poundbillion a year from poor peoples pockets. And the IFS think tank has warned ending austerity would cost around poundbillion. Chancellor Philip Hammond admitted any so-called end of austerity would only come next year in a full spending review, not in the Budget. And he confessed a No Deal Brexit could cancel the pledge altogether. We would need to look at a dferent strategy. And frankly wed need to have a new budget that set out a dferent strategy for the future, he said.

title: doctors give devastating news parents
story: NewsDoctors give devastating news to parents of toddler who kept tilting head to leftMum Zoe Archer, , knew something wasnt right with Alisha Riley after spotting her daughters unusual behaviourShareCommentsByKate McMullin:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsAlisha Riley in her new specialist buggy after her treatment, provided to her by Newle charity "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA devastated mother has told of how her toddler twin daughter kept tilting her head to left before being diagnosed with a deadly brain tumour. Mum Zoe Archer knew something wasnt right with Alisha Riley after spotting the unusual behaviour. And she trusted her instincts and took the little girl to the doctors where, after tests and scans, it was confirmed Alisha had a cancerous brain tumour. Zoe, from Huyton, Merseyside, first noticed the symptom in February when her daughter was  months old. The -year-old said Alisha, who has a twin brother Jack, was crawling when she saw the youngster was tilting her head to the left She told the Liverpool Echo: It was only slightly but she did it for a few days and I just thought she may have a bit of a stf neck. She wasnt crying with it and it wasnt stuck in that position. However days later Alisha began to vomit and the mum took her to AE.  She underwent a number of tests at both Alder Hey and Whiston Hospital which came back clear. But when she continued to deteriorate Alisha was given a scan - which is when doctors dealt the devastating blow that the youngster had a brain tumour. Zoe said: I knew she wasnt right. It was like she had gone back to being a two-month-old. I had to prop up cushions around her. It was like she was dizzy. Her eyes would roll and she wasnt able to keep down anything - she would just throw up. When they said it was a tumour it felt like my heart had stopped. I just looked at Alisha and started crying. Alisha was rushed to Alder Hey where doctors told her family she had a cm by cm tumour - the size of a golf ball. The tumour was located in her posterior fossa - an area in the brain responsible for critical s such as breathing, balance, speaking and co-ordination. Doctors firstly drained the fluid in Alishas brain and days later she had to undergo a nine hour surgery to remove the tumour. Zoe said: It just all wasnt really registering with me. Doctors were telling me of the risks of surgery and that my tiny baby could die. I was trying to listen, but it just wasnt going in. Although the surgery was a success, Alisha was not recovering as fast as doctors would have hoped and another scan showed the devastating reason why.  Alisha had a cancerous grade three brain tumour called an Ependymoma - which would grow back. Zoe said: We couldnt believe it. We had been happy because the surgery had been a success and had thought - the tumour had been removed so the cancer had been removed. The family were given a number of options including radiotherapy and chemotherapy - but due to her age both treatments came with their risks. Another option was a specialist treatment called proton beam therapy in Florida. And in June the family made the decision to fly to America for  weeks - in a bid to save their daughters le. A Go Fund me page, launched by Zoes brother Lee, raised more than pound, for the family - for their costs while out there. And after  rounds of treatment this week the family were given the fantastic news that Alishas scan was clear of cancer. Zoe said: I am so proud of how she has handled everything. She just kept smiling. Doctors have said she is about a year behind with her development, but she is getting there. She is learning to crawl again and Jack and her are playing together again. He has been great with her and will get down on the floor and crawl with her to get her going. Alisha has also been helped to move around by Newle - a charity for disabled children. Newle runs the only emergency loan service for children providing urgently needed, specialist equipment within hours, and provided a specialist buggy for Alisha. Zoe added: Because of her condition Alisha can’t sit up or support her own head, so she needs a specialist buggy with extra head support and chest straps to keep her in a stable position. Without that to keep her safe we couldn’t go. Now Alisha and her twin, Jack, are getting ready to celebrate their second birthday at the end of October. Le’s definitely not been easy and Alisha will have to have another scan in January, but we are over the moon. I think every time a scan is coming up we are going to be anxious. But now I will know the symptoms to look out for.

title: halloween one important rule remember
story: NewsHalloween: One important rule to remember while out trick or treatingA mum has a very important rule her children must follow when going from door to door asking for tasty treatsShareCommentsByAmber Hicks:,  OCT NewsOne mum has revealed her rule for trick or treating "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailIts that time of year again when youngsters don terrying costumes and go out and have a devilishly good time trick or treating as part of Halloween celebrations.The pumpkins come out, as do scary masks and decorations, to celebrate the spooky annual holiday. And one of the most enjoyable parts about it is children going from house to house and having their goodie bags filled with sweets and tasty treats.But people are being urged to remember one important thing when trick or treating - and it involves pumpkins.  If there is not a pumpkin or any decorations outside a house you are about to knock on, consider that the residents do not want to be disturbed.One mum told the Huffington Post: Our rule has always been you only trick or treat at houses that are decorated so no one is intimidated, our kids only allowed to go accompanied and only in our very local area. For many taking part, trick-or-treating is a great fun activity, but for others who may not welcome numerous callers to their door, it can be a very unnerving and stressful time. It is important for youngsters taking part to keep safe and ensure they respect people who do not wish to be part of the celebrations.If someone has a No Trick or Treaters flyer in the window, or no one answers the door, it means they do not want to participate.  Be mindful of the time too. If pumpkins have been blown out, take that as a don’t knock sign. As it starts to get very dark, thats a good time to head in. A Sussex Police spokesman said: If you are celebrating Hallowe’en, please consider the elderly and more vulnerable in the community who may find having strangers call at their door a frightening and intimidating experience. If you see someone displaying a no trick or treat poster, please do not call at those homes as people do not wish to be disturbed. Just be careful who you scare on Halloween. An Essex Police spokesman added: What might seem like being fun and mischievous to some can be really quite frightening to others.  Playing practical jokes on neighbours you don’t know or throwing things at their houses because they’re not taking part in trick or treat is unacceptable. In many cases it may actually be criminal in nature. If you decide to go trick or treating please think carefully about which doors you knock on, particularlyyou know there are elderly people living there. Some safety tips for Halloween by Sussex Police: For Trick or TreatersYoung children should always be accompanied by an adult. Older children should make sure an adult knows the area they plan to visit and what time they’ll be back Stay in well-lit areas where there are plenty of houses Keep to pavements and cross roads carefullyConsider calling only at houses where you know the occupants, rather than strangers.Explain how vulnerable people can be frightened by an unexpected group calling at their door on a dark evening. Respect the privacy and wishes of people who do not want to take part in trick or treat – observe the No Trick or Treaters please posters people may display in doors or windows For residents Residents are advised to continue to be vigilant when opening the door to strangers or unexpected callers. If you are prepared to receive Trick or Treaters, switch on your outside light and remove any trip hazards. If you set lanterns outside your front door with candles in them, make sure that they are far enough out of the way so that costumes wont accidentally be set on fire. Mr Thomas gave a speech of welcome in Maori, followed by a waiata, a song, from the group. “We’ve been watching your tour and we know you don’t get much time off,” Mr Thomas said. “I wouldn’t want to be a royal. So we don’t want to put any demands on you. We want you to enjoy yourself.All we want you to do is relax.”  The Duke, , struck an upbeat tone despite the drizzly weather, which cancelled a tree-planting ceremony. He and Meghan,  stayed inside a dry marquee for tea and cake with schoolchildren. Speaking after being formally welcomed by the Manawhenua ki Mohua people, Harry shared his excitement about visiting with a baby on board. He said: “The weather forecast was a lot worse than this. This rain is a blessing on all of us.From myself and my we and our little bump, we are so grateful to be here. “We bring blessings from my grandmother the Queen and our family. “We are so grateful for your hospitality and the work you do to look after this beautul place.”  The couple also strolled along the golden-sand beachfront on the nations South Island and discussed conservation with a ranger. Ranger Andrew Lamason told the pair that the creature is New Zealands version of a monkey due to its cheeky nature. Teenager Saskia Gray, a youth ambassador, said she was impressed by the Duke and Duchess. They acted very down-to-earth, and they genuinely care about the people and the land, said the -year-old. The couple later boarded their Royal New Zealand Air Force helicopter laden with gts, including a knitted blanket fit for a newborn baby.

story: NewsUK weather forecast: Britain set for coldest winter in eight years with temperatures to plunge from polar windForecasters believe temperatures could drop as low as -C in some parts of the United Kingdom with an even worse cold spell than the - Big FreezeShareCommentsByAlistair Grant:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT Newsthis.style.displaynone" Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news uk-news video cold-continue-through-next-week-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,video.header.bidding.enabled:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,video.header.bidding.enabled:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBritain is forecast the coldest winter for eight years – as frozen air from the North Pole triggers -Cshivers, snow and ice for many and transport chaos. Amid the first snow of winter, the country was warned of the worst winter since -, which saw December ’s month-long Big Freeze.Temperatures then reached as low as -C in the remote hamlet of Altnaharra in the Highlands of Scotland.The Met Office forecasts a mostly colder-than-average month ahead until late November. It has not yet issued its winter forecast. The Weather Company, the worlds biggest commercial forecaster, predicted the UK’s coldest winter for eight years, with December cold spells and extended January and February freezes.  Snow, -C lows and travel chaos are due. Arctic air plumes, a weak Atlantic jet stream and weakening solar output are blamed. This winter will be the coldest since -the UK’s average temperature from December to February is .C colder than winter’s .C average, Met Office records show. That would be colder than last winter – which saw the Beast from the East freeze the country and had an average temperature of .C - and winter -, which saw a month of Government health warnings as winter averaged .C.  Leon Brown, head of meteorological operations at The Weather Company’s Weather Channel arm, said: “The UK is looking at the coldest winter for eight years, since -. “After cold snaps in a mixed start to winter, we forecast the coldest periods with Arctic influence and snow in January and February.  “Low temperatures should exceed -C. Travel disruption is expected. “A strong Atlantic jet stream gives the UK a mild westerly flow with colder air trapped in the Arctic – but a weaker jet stream is forecast this winter, allowing Arctic air to drain south to the UK. “This causes much colder and longer-lasting cold periods than during a normal winter. “A colder winter is also expected due to the sun’s activity cycle approaching a ‘solar minimum,’ meaning there is less heat and energy reaching Earths atmosphere, contributing to weaker jet stream winds.”  The Weather Outlook forecaster Brian Gaze said: “The chance of winter - being cold or very cold has increased.” A Met Office forecast said: “Temperatures end October cold or rather cold, then recover. title: stunning meghan markle dazzles new
story: NewsStunning Meghan Markle dazzles New Zealand audience with celebration over womens right to voteMeghan Markle looked dazzling as she gave a speech praising New Zealand for being the first country to grant women the right to voteShareCommentsByRussell Myers:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT Newsthis.style.displaynone" Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news uk-news video watch-meghan-wears-black-give-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,video.header.bidding.enabled:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,video.header.bidding.enabled:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true""Get Royal Family updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe Duchess of Sussex celebrated women and the nation of New Zealand for being the first in the world to give women the vote. On the th anniversary of suffrage in the country, self-confessed feminist Meghan, honoured her hosts with a traditional Maori greeting of “tēnā koutou katoa” , meaning hello to you all. The Duchess told of her pride of being in the country that has such an important place in the history of women’s rights. She said: “The achievements of the women of New Zealand who campaigned for their right to vote, and were the first in the world to achieve it are universally admired.  “In looking forward to this very special occasion, I reflected on the importance of this achievement, but also the larger impact of what this symbolises. “Because yes - women’s suffrage is about feminism, but feminism is about fairness. “Suffrage is not simply about the right to vote but also about what that represents.  “The basic and fundamental human right of being able to participate in the choices for your future and that of your community. The involvement and voice that allows you to be a part of the very world you are a part of.” “And women’s suffrage is not simply about the right to vote for women but also about what that represents.  “The basic and fundamental human right of all people - including members of society who have been marginalised - whether for reasons of race, gender, ethnicity or orientation - to be able to participate in the choices for their future and their community. “So bravo New Zealand for championing this right  years ago - for the women who well deserve to have an active voice and acknowledged vote, and for all of the people that this effort has paved the way for globally.  “We all deeply thank you.” She ended her speech with a phrase from Kate Sheppard, who was the most prominent member of the women’s suffrage movement in New Zealand. The country’s most famous suffragette was born in Liverpool, and emigrated to New Zealand with her family in . Meghan, who looked stunning in a black Gabriela Hearstgown and a Maori inspired necklace, said: “In the words of your suffragette Kate Sheppard, “All that separates, whether race, class, creed, or sex, is inhuman, and must be overcome.”  The Duke and Duchess were invited to the residence by New Zealand’s Prime Minister, Jacinda Ardern, who asked them to attend thewith around  women chosen from local communities who are continuing to fight for women’s rights. The evening got off to a  start after the building had to be evacuated just moments before Meghan and Harry were due to be officially welcomed. As they were both getting ready in an upstairs room at the sprawling mansion built in , an unidentied person set off a smoke alarm in a downstairs toilet. An official later said it was believed to have been “steam or some form of atomiser”, perhaps an aerosol can, that had caused the  alarm. After a  minute delay, the Duke and Duchess were greeted first by the leader of the opposition, Simon Bridges and his we Natalie, before spending around  minutes warmly chatting to Ms Ardern, New Zealand’s third female Prime Minister.  They were welcomed my Dame Patsy Reddy, also the third woman to take up her post. Dame Reddy paid tribute to Kate Sheppard and heralded her contribution to the country’s and indeed the world’s suffrage history. She said: “Kate Sheppard is our Emmeline Pankhurst.  “Under her leadership, New Zealand women were the first in the world to achieve the right to vote –  years before the United Kingdom and  years before the United States. “Kate Sheppard and her fellow suffragists went door-to- door and town-to-town to get signatures for their monster suffrage petition. “They showed the power of women’s words to raise awareness and bring about change. “Kate was a superb communicator. “She used invincible logic in her appeals for justice, fairness and decency.  “She was an effective networker – galvanising other women into action, here and internationally.” The royals were treated to several traditional performances, including a six minute rendition from the poet laurette Dr Selina Tusitala Marsh. The Auckland-based Pacic poet and scholar receited her poem “Lead” about the concept of leadership and what it takes to achieve wellbeing in le. The celebrated high school trio Le Art also performed their song Choose Love. The schoolgirls shot to fame earlier this year when they posted an acapella version of the national anthem that received more than one million views on YouTube. The girls frm Porirua, a suburb of Wellington, called Meghan an inspiration and said it was a dream that she had come to hear them sing.

title: blether too cold for golf so local golf pro took up ice hockey with dundee rockets
story: The winter months usually mean time is sparse for playing rounds of golf.And this certainly was the case many years ago for one golf professional.So much so, that he got involved in a completely dferent sport – playing ice hockey with the Dundee Rockets!Graeme Hume was the professional at Downfield Golf Club from -, and he said: “Regarding playing then with the Rockets, I think I met Tom Stewart when he came to play golf at Downfield with Willie Murray.“Although I used to go to all the Rockets games, I was not involved, just a spectator, and also went to some away games.“Anyway, Tom allowed me to come up some Friday nights for a skate and let me have a go at some of the training exercises they did.“I was not much good I might add but I enjoyed every minute and it kept me fit!”This attracted Press attention at the time, as Graeme continued: “Ron Skelton, who was The Courier golf reporter at the time did a small article about what did golf pros do during the winter months and that was when he got a photo of me at the rink with the Rockets kit on.“This was circa winter , I think.“I never had any thoughts of playing ice hockey.“I just enjoyed watching the games and a bit of travelling with the team on away matches.”Some great names were involved with the Rockets then, as Graeme went on: “Other Rockets names I remember were Mike Mazur , Charlie Kinmond, Peem Lafferty, Joe Guilcher, Sammy McDonnald, Jimmy Penicuik, Mike Ward, Molly Reid, George Reid and Willie Murray.“I also got to know Derek Reillylater in le and played some golf with him – a great centre ice, poacher!“Some of the above are still playing hockey with the Old Timers on a Friday afternoon at Dundee Ice Arena.”Graeme currently lives in the Falkirk area and concluded: “I loved the Downfield club and all the people there.“We had a great junior section at that time.“My good friend Bill Barclay was one of those juniors at that time – and he has just won the Senior Club Championship.”

title: call for young men to mentor and transform lives of kids in dundee
story: A local mentoring charity is calling on more young men to volunteer.Breakthrough, which supports young people in Dundee, will be working with seven of the eight secondary schools in the city by January .The programme carefully matches up local mentors with vulnerable or care experienced young people in Dundee, to help them achieve their full potential.Jenny Paterson, chief executive officer of Breakthrough, said: “We need more volunteers, and particularly more men with trade backgrounds, because not every young person wants to go to college or university.“Dundee came second last in Scotland for care experienced young people who had positive destinations, so there’s work to be done. We have the chance to transform the whole city. Having a signicant person mentoring a young person makes a big dference in their le.”The project launched in August  and has had very positive responses from young people. The one-to-one scheme aims to help teenagers understand themselves better, increase their sense of wellbeing and reach positive destinations after school.Ms Paterson added: “Our mentors need to reflect the ersity of Dundee. It’s all about taking responsibility for changing the future of the city.”

title: callum booth keen to keep feelgood factor going at dundee united
story: Callum Booth is delighted to see everyone associated with Dundee United pulling in the same direction and he’s determined to reward today’s travelling support with more to cheer at Dunfermline.The Tangerines head to East End Park today for new manager Robbie Neilson’s third match in charge.Despite only being in charge for a couple of weeks now, United left-back Booth says the new gaffer has already made quite an impression.He said: “It’s been brilliant, really good. Training has been really good and I thinkyou asked any of the boys in the changing-room we’d all be the same.“It’s really gone up a level, we’re all enjoying it and I think that shows on a Saturday.“It’s been quite tough but I think we needed that. It’s been enjoyable at the same time, though, and we’re all buying into his ideas.”Off the field there seems to be an air of optimism around Tannadice but Booth knows getting results on the pitch is the only way to realise their hopes of promotion.And that means keeping their unbeaten run under the new boss going against a Dunfermline side that have already bagged a deserved win over the Tangerines.Booth added: “Four points from the first two games isn’t too bad but I think they were two good performances as well.“We feel hard done by we didn’t get the win over Inverness – I think most people there would agree with that but it wasn’t to be.“At least we put in a really positive performance and everyone is pulling in the same direction.“There is a good feel about the place and, hopefully, we can kick on now and go on a little run.“The players, coaching staff, fans all seem to be pulling in the same direction especially since the new gaffer has come in.“A thousand fans down at Partick, great backing and then same again last weekend. The fans were right with us until the last minute.“It does help, it makes a massive dference and Dunfermline isn’t too far down the road so I’d expect another good away following.“I think the fans can see the work and effort we’re putting in, evenwe didn’t get the three points last Saturday.“The fans have been great and long may it continue.”Allan Johnston’s Pars have been struggling of late after a lightning fast start to the season saw them follow up four wins from four in the Betfred Cup group stage with an impressive - victory at Tannadice.Since then, Dunfermline have only managed eight points from the following eight games and were beaten - at home last weekend despite dominating against Queen of the South.In fact, scoring goals at home has been a real problem of late with just the two Championship strikes going in.Booth  Co., however, are wary of a repeat show from the Pars.He said: “Dunfermline were really good at Tannadice the first time we played them and thoroughly deserved to win.“I think most people would be surprised they’ve not kicked on from that first game.“They played well that day and deserved the win.“I’ve not seen much of them since but it’s not worked out for them since for whatever reason.“They’ll still be a dangerous opponent, though, because they are, obviously, capable of putting in a performance but have just been a bit inconsistent recently.“If we go about it like we have done in the last two games then we’ll give ourselves a chance.“We’ll be going there in positive spirits, try to take our chances and come back up the road with the three points.”

title: cash raised for upkeep of dundee station piano
story: An all-star charity concert has raised a further £, for the upkeep of the new “people’s piano” at Dundee train station.The gig, held at Clarks on Lindsay Street, brought musicians from across the city together to perform to ensure the instrument’s future maintenance costs are covered.Dundonians had already raised £, to buy the replacement after the original was smashed shortly after its installation.The piano was donated to the new £ million station by local man Dave Patterson in memory of his late we Jean, a former ScotRail employee, who died earlier this year.Performances included acoustic sets by The Collective, Revolver, The Mess Arounds, Abandon, The Interceptors and Julie  Claire from the Funkin’ Idiots.Also playing were the Love Puppets, David Webster, Gavin McGinty, Alice Marra and Colin Reid, George Harris, Kieron Smart and Stephen Knight.Mr Patterson said: “It was a special night and the performances were all fantastic.“Some of the artists performed the song Piano Man at the end for me which was so touching.”The event was organised by Kit Clark, of s pop group Danny Wilson.The cash will be kept in a charitable trust, with any excess being donated to Alzheimer’s Scotland.

title: dundee appoint jimmy boyle as new assistant manager
story: Dundee have appointed Jimmy Boyle as assistant manager to Jim McIntyre.The -year-old steps up from his post as head of the Dark Blues youth academy to team up with the new boss who arrived to succeed Neil McCann last week.Jimmy has been in the dugout for the games against Livingston and Hearts and confirmation he’s to remain their permanently brings to an end the Billy Dodds saga that’s dragged on since the new manager arrived last week.Dodds, who was Jim’s number two at Ross County, was his first choice for the same post at Dens Park, but well documented matters relating to his departure after Dundee went into administration in  made him unacceptable to many Dark Blues fans.As well as him, it’s understood Dens legend Barry Smith and Aberdeen coach Barry Robson were also being considered.But Jim has opted for another man he knows well and who has extensive experience in coaching and management.The pair played together at Airdrie and during eight years with the Diamonds, Jimmy appeared in two Scottish Cup finals.After a career that included spells at a string of clubs including Queen’s Park, Livingston and Partick Thistle, he was Airdrie’s under- coach for several seasons before succeeding Kenny Black as manager in .He was sacked three years later, but was quickly appointed to the SFA’s coaching staff and in  was headhunted by Dundee to take charge of developing their emerging talent.Over the last two-and-half-years he’s transformed the fortunes of the club’s underage sides and last season saw him steer the Development squad to a second place finish in their league.Known for someone who prefers to stay out of the limelight, he has been persuaded to make the step back up to first team level and assist his old team-mate in keeping Dundee in the Premiership.A Dundee FC statement said: #Jimmy has been with the club since joining as head of youth development in . During that period he has overseen the academy while also managing the development side and helping out with the first team.

title: dundee linked with move for ex ross county and dundee united defender
story: Another former Ross County player could be on Jim McIntyre’s radar.It emerged on Wednesday, Martin Woods has been training with Dundee and could be the new Dens Park boss’ first signing.And now there’s speculation defender Paul Quinn could also join up.Like Woods, Quinn played under Jim up in Dingwall. The -year-old moved to Dundee United last year but his appearances were limited by injury and illness.And he would have to prove his fitness before being given a contract with the Dark Blues.Meanwhile, the matter of who will be the new assistant boss at Dundee could be resolved soon.Billy Dodds is the manager’s preferred choice but as is now clear his arrival would be unpopular with many fans.Others in the frame include Aberdeen coach Barry Robson and possibly even former Dee skipper, and one-time manager, Barry Smith.Whoever gets the nod should be in place for next week’s clash with Celtic.

title: dundee people celtic lisbon lions 80th birthday surprise
story: Lochee lad Charlie Walker has turned  – and it was marked with a bang.His family couldn’t see the milestone pass without a celebration, so brother Andy and daughter Annie set out to organise a surprise party at the Dee Club.Andy said: “My niece phoned me and told me that she was wanting to host a surprise party for her dad’s birthday.“She tasked me with getting all his friends together.“I managed to get his pals from as far back as  in Fintry, to his first friend from Ancrum Road Primary School.“In all we managed to get  family and friends together.“When he came into the club and the lights turned on and everyone was singing Happy Birthday he was absolutely gobsmacked – for the first time in years.“Usually Charlie always has a funny comment but not that night.“He was just so shocked that it was all for him.”Asthose  people weren’t enough, one of Charlie’s footballing heroes, former Celtic star John Hughes, also made a special appearance – bringing with him the European Cup won by the club in .Andy added: “I have been mates with big John for years and got to know him very well.“When I asked himhe fancied a night with a dference he said ‘oh that sounds amazing’.“No one knew that John was coming except myself and my two sons.“I didn’t even tell Annie.“The night was just a fantastic celebration with music and good company.“It was like a big family reunion with relatives that we haven’t seen in  years even coming along.“Charlie has had some le and he is totally loved in Lochee.“He has such a big heart and is always wanting to help others.“For his birthday Charlie also decided that he just wanted a collection of money that can be donated to a charity.“We would all like to say a massive thank you to everyone who came along and also to the amazing staff at the Dee Club.”

title: dundee students overcome odds to graduate at ceremony
story: Almost , people descended on the Caird Hall to celebrate Dundee and Angus College’s annual graduation ceremony.Approximately  students who have successfully completed Higher National programmes such as HNC or HND, BA degree, SVQ, VTCT and PDA awards crossed the stage, supported by , family members and friends.Among them were Shaun Stickland and Ellan Ryder, pictured, who both graduated from the college’s Scottish School of Contemporary Dance after overcoming serious setbacks. Shaun has a pacemaker and Ellen’s boyfriend died during her third year at college.Shaun said: “I had heart surgery during the summer but I’ll hopefully be back performing soon. My time at college not only allowed me to work with industry professional artists but also to make some amazing friends and have a great support system to explore my own creative ideas.”Ellen said: “This was an incredibly hard time for me but I had a lot of support from my friends, family and the college staff.”

title: dundee united is perfect platform for striker pavol safranko
story: Robbie Neilson says Dundee United are giving star striker Pavol Safranko the perfect  to show off his ability.The Slovakian international joined the Tangerines on loan while former boss Csaba Laszlo was still in charge to regain the form that saw Aalborg shell out a six-figure sum last summer.The move to Denmark hasn’t worked out but four goals in his last five games during his loan spell at Tannadice has helped new boss Robbie get off to a positive start with a win and a draw in his first two games.And the new United gaffer is delighted he’s got a player like Safranko to lead the line, evenhe accepts the Slovakian is likely to only be a one-season wonder.He said: “I’ve been very impressed with Pavol, very impressed. He’s definitely one of our key players.“He links the game well, has good strength, very good mobility and a good attitude as well – the rest of the players really like him as well which is a big thing.“You need a striker to lead the line for you that can handle the physicality because the game gets like that in Scotland.“Last Saturday there were a few hefty challenges but he stood up to it. I have been impressed, I think he’s a very good player.“He got a good move before but has had a dficult time since.“However, we’ve given him a  to rebuild himself and I think it’s a good window for him to show what he can do.”Neilson has also revealed he’s upped the tempo in training since taking the reins to get the best out of his new squad.He added: “We have just been trying to get the intensity up in training a wee bit.“When I came in, I looked at all the data at what they had done previously and what I felt I would try to implement because I have dferent ideas about what to do.“I just felt we needed to do something a wee bit dferent to try to get a spark in the team and get some enjoyment.“What you want to do when you come in is work them really, really hard to get them as fit as you can as quick as you can. But you also have to realise where their base is so you can minimise injuries.“We have been pretty lucky with that with only Paul Watson getting a wee tweak in his thigh last week.“The base was good, it was fine and I was happy with it but I just wanted to bring more intensity to training to make it shorter and sharper.”

title: dundee united women on the road to the top after league win
story: Dundee United Women are already looking ahead to next season after clinching the Scottish Women’s Football League One title at Tannadice Park after an emphatic victory over Cove Rangers.It was the first time the United girls had played an official match on Tannadice itself and it turned out to be extra special with silverware presented at the end of a - win.Captain Keira Johnstone said: “I am massively proud of the girls and what we have achieved.“It was a big day for us and the team performed brilliantly.“Everyone has worked hard, players and coaches, to gain promotion to the Scottish Women’s Premier League . We can’t wait to get started next season.”Head coach Gavin Beith added: “To finish the season off the way we did was very pleasing and doing this at Tannadice made it such a special day for everyone involved.“On and off the park so many people have worked extremely hard over the years to support the team and it’s a fitting way to cap off a good season.“Playing SWPL football is going to be exciting for us all.”Paul Wilson, the Community Coaching Manager, commented: “I’m delighted. title: dundee woman living off 8 a week has debt written off thanks to money advice group
story: An estimated £ million of benefits owed to Dundee residents has been clawed back this year thanks to a team of financial advisers.A city-based financial support service has helped  people with their money troubles since January, having identied £m of local people’s debt.Dundee Money Action provides long-term advice, assistance and support to people who are in debt, struggling to heat their homes or trying to save for the future.Among the  people it has helped to take control of their finances is one vulnerable woman who managed to claim £, of backdated benefits payments.Sammy Heenan, financial support officer for the group said: “She had been on the wrong benefits for three years.“It was quite obvious because she hadn’t been working but she wasn’t getting access to things like free dental treatment.“She was living off of £ a week and that was to feed her son, heat the house and look after her pets as well.”Within weeks, the service helped her access £ per week and a payment of more than £, of backdated money that she had been entitled to.All of the woman’s debt was also written off, as the lending was classed as “irresponsible”, due to the woman’s vulnerable status.Sammy said: “We worked with her a lot after she settled and she felt like she had a voice again.“We built up her confidence and encouraged her and now she’s doing absolutely great.”Dave Morris, project manager, said: “We provide support like looking at income expenditure, home energy checks and debt resolution.“We also provide literacy support to help people understand letters they receive.“We deliver everything in a holistic approach.”

title: spooky dundee fancy dress boss reveals this years must have halloween costumes
story: Villains and spooky spectres are among the top picks for Halloween party-goers this year.David Farry, of Yvonne’s Fancy Dress on the Seagate, revealed the shop’s biggest sellers in the run-up to October  have been more traditional costumes.He said that following several years of guisers opting for less typical outfits, there’s a trend for clothes that really embrace the spirit of the scariest time of the year.David said: “There’s been a big push on well-known characters like Slenderman – a child- snatching monster dreamt up on internet message boards – along with killer clowns like Pennywise from the remake of It.“And with the new Halloween film out there’s been big demand for costumes of Michael Myers.“We still do a lot of ‘generic’ costumes but people like to make them scary. People are buying costumes of Dorothy from the Wizard of Oz and Little Red Riding Hood and adding blood and cuts.”Social media has given a  to budding make-up artists, who use their skills to create some truly grisly effects.For those who don’t have a make-up artist to hand, Yvonne’s has also stocked up on a iety of “kits” offering everything from cuts and scars through to more elaborate – and gory – bodily injuries.David added: “It’s usually the kids more than the adults who want to add gore, blood and guts. Even little girls and boys.“It used to be that people wanted to dress up as less scary things at Halloween but that tide has turned again.“Superhero characters like Deadpool and Harley Quinn from Suicide Square are still very popular but there’s a lot more demand for horror.”For those who do prefer their look to be more current, Yvonne’s has up-to-date costumes, including a “carry-me” one showing Donald Trump riding on the back of Kim Jong-un.For those coming in to buy their wicked wares, David added that there’s no need to be scared.“All of our staff get dressed up and slap on the make-up – it’s more fun for the customers to see us like this,” he said.“Adults can be a bit sheepish but when they see us totally involved in it they really go for it.”

title: work on track to complete two pedestrian crossings on kingsway
story: The second phase of work to install two new pedestrian crossings on the Kingsway is due to finish on schedule.Workers have been carrying out extensive surfacing improvements on the ide between the eastbound and westbound stretches of the carriageway between Old Glamis Road and Forfar Road.Alterations have been carried out during off-peak hours, with lane closures taking place between .pm-.am to minimise disruption.The latest phase of works has involved metal studs and markings being laid on the road surface, along with footways at the points where the Kingsway meets Graham Street and Mains Loan.A spokeswoman for Dundee City Council confirmed the latest phase of the project was due to be completed by Saturday.It is understood that further works will be required to install the traffic lights themselves along with the systems required to make them work.The local authority’s plans to install the pedestrian-operated Toucan crossings on the Kingsway are part of its wider efforts to encourage the use of sustainable transport.Funded by a grant from the Scottish Government through its Cycling, Walking and Safer Streets scheme, the crossings will link Dundee south of the Kingsway with Caird Park.The carriageway has been viewed by city planners as a “major barrier” for cyclists and pedestrians wanting to travel to the north or south of the city.Fears of disruption caused by the signals have previously been allayed by council officials, who said the lights will operate on an “on-demand” basis rather than on a timed cycle.A date for the next phase of the works is yet to be set and no further comment on the works was available from the council.
